content.description:
Leftmost route on the wall. Start off the wooden platform.

P1- 5.10+ Climb up and left through an overhang.  Short pitch. 

P2- 5.10+ Climb up and left through another overhang.  Short pitch.

P3- 5.10+/11- Up and left through a steep corner, then straight up through a smaller overhang (crux). 

P4- .10- A short vertical section leads to a right angling, techy face and a return to the top of the wall.


bolts

Three pitches that follow the rap descent. Pitches 1 and 2 travel over exposed aretes and make for some really exciting climbing. The holds are massive and route finding shouldn't be an issue.

P1.  10a.  Start on the ledge and trend left, before trending back right to the rappel line. Follow the first line of bolts up an arete and belay directly above the belayer on a slab.

P2.  10b.  Wildly exposed moves on big holds move left to a dihedral. Continue straight up to bolted anchor.  We considered this the money pitch. 

P3. 10b.  Goes straight up a slightly overhanging wall of jugs. Then switch it up by trending right (pass rap anchors) and go all the way to top of the wall. Some moss to navigate around, but still enjoyable climbing.


Start on the the base ledge. First pitch trend up and left. 

All bolted. Approximately 11, 16, and 18(ish) bolts on pitches 1, 2 and 3 respectively (assuming pitch 3 is climbed to the top). Consider taking some Alpine draws to extend some wandery bolts (but not mandatory).

The second (middle buttress) at Waterworld. Very well marked by signs. Faces west and gets hit with afternoon sun.

 You can get to water level ledge in 3 raps with a 70m or 4 with a 60m rope.  Rappell descent is straight forward but a guidebook topo would be wise to have. Clip two looped slings to your gear loops and use the saddle bag method to avoid getting wet ropes on the last rappel.
